column10: Do you believe that the right to repair should be protected and that manufacturers should be made to make their products repair-friendly?

column3: For stuff like fitbits I’d want to know that I could change straps easily. For most stuff (Alexas, TVs, iPhones, iPads) no, because they look too complicated and I know I can get them repaired by posting them off. Computers I’d quite happily test/replace components, but wouldn’t try to repair an individual component, eg power supply, motherboard, etc.

column3: Answered sometimes because I could not categorically say yes or no. It is certainly something I would be seriously concerned about but believe it is not something manufacturers are concerned about, in fact I believe some may actually inhibit repair and design in obsolescence. If any device I owned failed I would initially try to find a way to repair before anything else. I suspect that this is an 'age' matter more practised by older people than younger generations - a question of upbringing.

column3: Things like phones, tablets etc I'd be happy to repair a cracked screen or replace a circuit board, so might check for availability of parts. Usually it's more a case that I don't consider it at purchase but am happy to take things apart and see if it's fixable if it happens to break. It would be a factor of something was known to be hard to repair (i.e. by design), I'd be more likely to avoid buying it.

column3: I would for kitchen equipment and white goods as i have had good experience with repairing our Britannia oven and Miele washing machine as they appear to be engineered so they can be repaired. column3: Measured by the potential obsolescence of the device. Phones usually I'm covered by insurance, but I have also done repairs myself (e.g. screen replacement for HTC One S, attempted laptop fixes - upon failure, removal and backup of SSDs). White goods I'm more likely to be concerned with repairability and cost to do so (e.g. Miele repairs are costly, so off-putting). With a mobile phone I am likely to change in 2.5-3 years due to inevitable performance issues and repairs are less likely if I am a careful user.
